After a short stint in the political wilderness, Clegg resurfaced at Facebook in 2018 to serve as the vice president for global affairs and communications.

It was a disastrous move for @LibDems that destroyed trust in the party and its leadership. They haven't recovered since.

Clegg resigned from the party's leadership in 2015, but kept his Commons seat ‚Äî only to lose it two years later.

https://t.co/DPg5uqfzuX https://t.co/YnXxLk2Y8i

In their election manifesto, @LibDems had promised to fight hikes to university tuition fees, a policy that attracted the votes of students.

But coalition means compromise, and the @LibDems and @Conservatives voted to raise tuition fees.

https://t.co/DPg5uqfzuX

.@LibDems went on to form a coalition government with @Conservatives, with Clegg as @David_Cameron's deputy prime minister.

Clegg was the first Liberal leader since 1922 to serve in government ‚Äî and arguably, the biggest failure ever to hold that post.

https://t.co/DPg5uqfzuX

In 2007, Clegg became the leader of @LibDems, the UK's third-largest political party at the time.

A phenomenon that the press labeled "Cleggmania" swept the UK after his straightforward approach in debates during the 2010 general-election campaign.

https://t.co/DPg5uqfzuX

Clegg worked as a journalist at @FT in the early '90s before becoming a policy advisor and speechwriter to Leon Brittan at @EU_Commission. 

He was later elected as a member of the @Europarl_EN in 1999 and to @HouseofCommons in 2005.

https://t.co/DPg5uqfzuX

Sir Nicholas William Peter Clegg, 54, enjoyed a privileged upbringing.
